column1: Congratulations also to John Kerry on his appointment to help get us back on track to taking on climate change.

I am honored to extend congratulations to @AliMayorkas @ABlinken Avril Haines Janet Yellen @LindaT_G and @jakejsullivan on their nominations to serve in the Biden Administration.  We are one step closer to getting on with the people’s business.  America’s back!

Have you been impacted by COVID-19? You may be eligible for a relief grant through the @OrangeCoFL CARES Fund. The application portal will reopen Tues Nov. 24 at 8 a.m. for 15000 users. This is one of the last chances to apply.   For more info visit https://t.co/xvry6nV61i. https://t.co/fWxMr9aa6H
This is not some mystery. Taking precautions against covid saves lives. Refusal to follow the science is the act of a cult. Use your brain and protect the people you love. https://t.co/c3zxz2tBAU

Sometimes your side loses elections. That’s democracy. To throw around baseless claims of fraud with no evidence undermines our republic and threatens our most precious freedoms. It’s time for the GOP to find their backbones and rein in this reckless president.
We need the GOP to come back to the negotiating table and pass real help for restaurants and other small businesses. Otherwise they may not survive the winter. https://t.co/3V8liE7byE
Wishing a very happy birthday to President-elect Biden and to my sister Hazel. Birthdays are Blessings.
Proud of @MCO for being awarded the Global Biorisk Advisory Council (GBAC) STAR accreditation for cleaning protocols disinfection techniques and related efforts to combat COVID-19.

By refusing to pass federal covid relief GOP politicians have put local leaders in an impossible position. Individuals and businesses need federal support in order to limit the spread of the virus while still making ends meet. It’s not a luxury it’s required. https://t.co/oz1rp726ke

FACTS:  President-elect Biden will be sworn in.  Trump throwing a tantrum will not change the result.  Trump officials refusing to coordinate with the transition will cause Americans to needlessly die.  GOP leaders allowing this to continue are complicit.

Bipartisan governors beg you: limit your Thanksgiving festivities this year. Protect your loved ones. https://t.co/fjUJzEnhO6

America what is President Trump doing? He lost and is now trying to overturn the will of the people while the GOP does nothing.  History WILL remember those who did not have the courage to fight for our democracy.

Governor DeSantis has hired an unqualified conspiracy theorist and Ohio sports blogger as part of Florida's COVID-19 response. He is putting the health and safety of all Floridians at risk. Our response must be based on scientific and medical evidence.

President Trump banned diversity and inclusion training programs in the federal government because…you know why. I cosponsored @RepBeatty's legislation to renew them.

100 years ago a man named July Perry had the audacity to believe that he and his Black neighbors should have the right to vote. He was killed for that belief.  I was honored to speak at his Last Rites Ceremony this weekend following the 100th anniversary of the Ocoee Massacre. https://t.co/vax6XNVQIM
Join us this Thursday at 7:00pm for a tele-town hall on veterans services. Call 855-962-1334 to join. https://t.co/byqc3p7chs
I'm eager to get back to work to restore the promise of America and give every person a safe and prosperous future.
I am so proud of everyone who worked to make this moment happen and I am thrilled to congratulate President-elect Biden and Vice President-elect Harris on their historic victory.
Four years ago we took a step backwards. Today the American people showed up in record numbers to restore honor competence and empathy to the White House.
It is a monument to the fact that America has not always lived up to our promise but that each generation has worked struggled and sacrificed to build a more perfect union.
When I heard the news I was at the graveside of July Perry the Black voting rights advocate killed 100 years ago in the Ocoee Massacre.
Democracy won. https://t.co/PAbCcnj7gj
Let’s get to work. https://t.co/5DVABNWTNc

This election was about our democracy our decency and about building a more perfect union where all of us get a fair shot.  Now the hard work begins for a brighter future ahead. Let's get to it.
Democracy will win.

Thank you Mayor Johnson @cityofocoeeFL and High Point Church for hosting a candlelight vigil and program honoring the memory of all victims of the Ocoee Massacre. We must remember all victims of this injustice. https://t.co/Ae3bBjve6v

As #covid resurges I implore you: wear a mask physically distance from others and wash hands and surfaces regularly. We cannot let this pandemic take the lives of our loved ones.
Count every vote.

One party is trying to protect your right to vote. One party is trying to make sure it’s hard or that your vote is thrown out.  These are not equally valid strategies and we have a responsibility to not normalize attempts to destroy our democracy.

.@HouseDemocrats have been fighting for your right to vote.  House Resolution 1 which I cosponsored was a comprehensive overhaul of voting rights and good government legislation.  The GOP Senate blocked this anti-corruption package.
I believe that my vote in the election counts just the same as anyone else’s. I want my vote to be counted and that means I want your vote to be counted too.
Dedication! https://t.co/tsh7OsvK7B
Incredible! https://t.co/OKS7BLz60d

🚨FLORIDA: False robocalls are spreading misinformation to try to silence your voice.  Don’t be fooled:  You must vote TODAY before 7:00p (but stay in line if you’re in line at 7:00!)  Look up your polling location here: https://t.co/e1vJmllhDL  Make your #vote count.

E pluribus unum - out of many one.  We have stumbled along our journey. We have made mistakes. But through bravery sacrifice compassion and honor generations of Americans have worked to build a more perfect union.  Now it's time to take the next step.  Happy Election Day.

Every American should vote and every vote should be counted.

https://t.co/BVguzNBgYG

In 1920 the Klan had said 'any ******* who tries to vote brutal harm will come to them.'  July Perry—he voted."  Today on the 100th anniversary of the Ocoee Massacre listen to Glenn Barbour tell the story of this event and its significance. https://t.co/7TQEOWTjny

“SPECIAL BARGAINS: Several beautiful little groves belonging to the Negroes that just left Ocoee” read his advertisement.  Those who excuse today’s inequalities without recognizing our nation’s history of theft and racial violence do a disservice to the truth. https://t.co/6XoziWVaCC

Those who attempted to return faced threats or overt acts of violence including “dynamite thrown into their homes.”  Their property was seized and sold. One local official a confederate veteran who had fought to preserve slavery took ownership of some.

100 years ago today Moses Norman a Black man in Ocoee Florida tried to vote.  This challenge to the racial order caused a white mob to lynch voting rights activist July Perry and with further violence to murder or eventually drive out every other Black resident in the town. https://t.co/vfrPfVM4mk
In the 1960s Susie was one of a group of 25 young people who protested for civil rights. Here's what she thinks of today's protests: https://t.co/HwMqdwDldj https://t.co/cxlewSufEN
Susie Forehand's memories of Rosa Parks and segregated buses in Orlando.  Change is always possible. Never give up. https://t.co/DoDEMYczta

And this is the first time I got arrested.  Generations of Americans put their lives and freedom on the line in the struggle for our rights today. Honor them by following their legacy and by making sure your vote counts. https://t.co/gewgsg1Bxu
Here Ms. Forehand describes her first sit-in.  "We had to be careful." https://t.co/cA1wq9ZCWD

We always knew there was something better than what we had.  As a teenage activist in the 1960s Susie Forehand risked her safety for the rights and freedoms we enjoy today. As we go into Election Day I hope that every American will go forward with her same bravery and energy. https://t.co/wedw6zX1pN
Joining @FaceTheNation with @margbrennan in just a few minutes.

Those days you were afraid that because you were Black someone was going to kill you. You're going to die. You get lynched you get shot something will happen.  Vote. Too many people have sacrificed too much for you to stay at home. https://t.co/pDcajZapdD

The administration has taken the side of big polluters. It will lead to sickness premature deaths and environmental damage especially in and around low-income communities.  It’s the wrong side and I joined @RepDMP to strongly oppose rules that put profits before our health.

The vaccine process must be totally above politics and completely based on science. I again call on the administration to stop politicizing the health and safety of the American people and undermining the FDA’s efforts to keep us safe.
@sddphoto Yes we must do more. Our legislation in the House included funding to ensure first responders can stay on the job safely. Republicans in the Senate refused to allow a vote on it.

This week we celebrate our first resonders; we honor the men and women who risk their lives to keep us safe by putting service before self. Thank you for everything you do and for always being there for us.

America is at our best when we work with other nations as a global leader. I joined @RepJudyChu and @BradSherman to call for a restoration of decades of successful international coordination on global health. A global pandemic needs a global response.

Amy Coney Barrett ruled that a supervisor who called a Black employee the n word HADN’T created a hostile work environment. If she can’t understand why having a racist boss is a problem she shouldn’t sit on the Supreme Court.

I wrote to the court to oppose Texas’ efforts to stop voters from being able to drop off their ballots. The election chicanery this year is a great example of why the Supreme Court matters. The gutting of the Voting Rights Act paved the way for this year’s corruptions.

Our democracy means more than any one election or any one president. Protecting our God-given rights is a calling higher than petty party politics.  By refusing to answer whether President Trump could delay the election Justice Barrett showed that she doesn’t understand that.

The craziness of the last four years does not have to be our future. I still believe that a better saner politics and country is possible. We can respect one another protect civil rights create opportunity and prosperity. Never lose faith.

Larry has lived a remarkable life of faith family service duty honor—and fun: skiing scuba-diving parachuting learning to fly a plane gardening playing music travel and more.  I'm proud to represent him and to wish him a very happy birthday. https://t.co/giH0Hg2Nm1
Faith has always been important to Larry not just during the war but also after.  He helped establish Winter Garden's Seventh-day Adventist Church as well as others around the country.

After the war Larry came back home and took his GED. He met his future wife Lois while working on a Christmas committee and both would go on to become nurses.  They had six children (not to mention ten grandchildren and two great-grandchildren).

Larry bravely served in Italy France and Germany. Here is a letter written for a local newspaper by two men whose lives he helped save in Europe an act of courage that earned him the Bronze Star. https://t.co/nip1W0ZFBS

Fortunately with the help of friendly local pastors and a considerate colonel he managed to achieve a transfer to a medical unit attached to his anti-aircraft battalion. He travelled to Africa then Europe.

This led to longstanding conflicts between him and his commanding officers. He had to hold strong against immense pressure—even a threat of court martial and the death penalty.  As he said afterward “I have to admit I did a lot of praying."

Larry was born to a large family in Wisconsin and after graduating from 8th grade dropped out of school to work on his family's farm.  In 1942 he was drafted into the U.S. Army. But as a devout Seventh-day Adventist he refused to take life or to train to take one.

Please join me in wishing Mr. Larry Cheever a happy 100th birthday.  A man of faith and family who was decorated as a medic during World War II Mr. Cheever worked as a nurse for decades and lives in Winter Garden.  Birthdays are blessings. Happy birthday! https://t.co/uV6h9yHrZC

I was glad to wish Ms. Parker a happy and blessed 100 years on her birthday this weekend! https://t.co/H35XjMn1N9

She moved to Florida in 2009 where she lives in assisted living playing games and chatting with friends. She is described as an incredibly loving and caring person and is beloved by the staff and other residents there.

Over the course of Dorothy's 100 years she has been married three times surviving two of her husbands as they passed away. She has had a life full of challenges and adversity yet she maintains a sunny positive outlook and incredible zest for life.

Over time she taught herself how to care for even the most difficult patients becoming their go-to problem solver. She credits that work with giving her great patience and love for all people especially the mentally ill.
When Dorothy was older it was suggested that she too clean homes. Instead she chose to work as an aide at a mental institution in Chicago. She started at the very bottom but learned quickly.

Eventually she moved to Chicago and lived with her grandmother who was a house servant for a wealthy family.  She attended school only until the third grade continuing her studies at the kitchen table.

Dorothy was born to Cordelia Brown an African American woman and Louis Klyce a German man. Both of her parents worked as janitors.  She remembers being ridiculed for her skin and living in fear of the KKK in Illinois when she was young.

On #InternationalWomensDay we celebrate all women and the incredible contributions of women today and throughout our history.  Here’s one story—the unparalleled  and indomitable Ida B. Wells. #InternationalWomensDay2020 https://t.co/1UD5MpjYdH

Last month a century after Ida B. Wells exposed the horrors of lynching the U.S. House of Representatives voted to make lynching a federal crime for the first time. I was proud to cast that long-overdue vote.
Her legacy lives on today anywhere someone speaks truth to power or fights for the rights of those who lack them. #InternationalWomensDay  https://t.co/Svk4jvbEXb

More than fifty years before Rosa Parks Wells sat in a “Whites Only” train car.  After she was forced off she organized an economic boycott that became a model for the Civil Rights Movement five decades later. https://t.co/REvmsxys1c
Said Frederick Douglass one of the finest writers and orators in American history “There has been no word equal to it in convincing power...I have spoken but my word is feeble in comparison.”

But that truth-telling wasn’t without consequences. “After her anti-lynching editorials were published in The Free Speech she was run out of the South — her newspaper ransacked and her life threatened.”  She kept going.

Wells “pioneered reporting techniques that remain central tenets of modern journalism” according to the @nytimes.  Called “The Princess of the Press” her “fine-tooth reporting methods” and bold language made her a sensational truth-teller. https://t.co/bydBaV0ZFc
She exposed that many lynching victims accused of rape had in fact had consensual relationships with white women.  “She was called a harlot and a courtesan for her frankness.”

Ida B. Wells made it her mission to fight for justice and particularly to expose lynchings of Black men as hate crimes.  It was not a punishment for crimes she wrote but “an excuse to get rid of Negroes who were acquiring wealth and property.” https://t.co/qGsUcq6pQO

Ida’s parents died when she was 16. She dropped out of school lied about her age and became a teacher to support her siblings.  At the same time the dream of Reconstruction was dying and the violent authoritarianism of Jim Crow racism was rising.

Ida B. Wells was born a slave. She faced prejudice all her life. Less than five feet tall her massive presence left a permanent mark on America leaving behind a legacy of journalistic excellence and social change.  Here’s her story. #InternationalWomensDay https://t.co/zCkj6PNzLu

As we end #BlackHistoryMonth I’m remembering the first responders who led the way for those of us who followed. We stand on the shoulders of giants.  We also give thanks to all our first responders. We know that when they are as diverse as our community we are all safer.
Davell Davis Jimmy Hawkins Harley Leak Tim Jackson Willie Green and Samuel Williams were Orlando’s first Black @OrlandoFireDept firefighters.
Louis Crooms Leroy Williams Tommy Ward Jimmie Randle Luis Demps Roosevelt Sealey and William Williams were the first Black deputies for the @OrangeCoSheriff.

Despite these challenges they served Orlando with professionalism and distinction.  Belvin Perry Sr. Richard Arthur Jones John W. Jordan Otha Lee Kelly Mayo Howard and Gainous Wright were the first Black officers for the @OrlandoPolice

When @OrlandoPolice’s first Black officers—Belvin Perry Sr. and Richard Arthur Jones—began their careers in 1951 they had secondhand cars and no radios.  They could issue arrests but if the suspect was white they weren’t allowed to take them to jail. #BlackHistoryMonth #BHM https://t.co/6HtyJlHvMS

In her Last Will & Testament she wrote "Faith courage brotherhood dignity ambition responsibility -- these are needed today as never before...The Freedom Gates are half-ajar. We must pry them fully open." #BlackHistoryMonth #BHM https://t.co/VEAUFbH47j

The remainder of her life was devoted to education and the fight for liberty. She worked with the National Council of Negro Women and National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. She went to the U.N. She continued to fight for her school. https://t.co/L5HAozKxd1
In 1936 Roosevelt appointed her as director of the Division of Negro Affairs of the National Youth Administration where she worked to employ over 300000 young people.
She became an advisor to five U.S. presidents. She was one of President Roosevelt’s closest advisers and one of Eleanor Roosevelt’s closest friends. https://t.co/B3DvNXk5av

Word of her bravery and abilities spread. She served in leadership roles in Florida’s premier civil rights organizations where she fought for educational opportunity voting rights child welfare workers’ rights and an end to lynchings.

From these humble beginnings her impact swiftly grew. She expanded her school founded the first Black hospital in Daytona fought for civil rights opened the first public library for Black Floridians and faced down a KKK mob. https://t.co/rfJ9p0p344

She moved to Florida with a dollar and fifty cents in her pocket and teaching a first class of five students in a bare-bones room.  Her school the Bethune Institute for Girls would later merge with the Cookman Institute for Boys to form @bethunecookman. https://t.co/dYAektiEoY

When no missionary opportunities were available she turned to education teaching for almost a decade and marrying fellow teacher Albertus Bethune. Then in a decision that would change history she purchased a small cottage in Florida.

That story starts in a small missionary school five miles from the farm where her family worked. She was the only member of her family to go to school. She walked each way doing her schoolwork by candlelight.

Mary McLeod was the 15th child to former slaves.  Over the course of her extraordinary life she became one of America’s leading advocates for education civil and voting rights the founder of @bethunecookman and an advisor to five U.S. presidents. #BlackHistoryMonth #BHM https://t.co/aKByP3gIG3

He went on to roles in film and television radio business music and philanthropy helping other young people to rise above what other people told them they should be.  He died in 2013 the "greatest defensive end of modern football."

Said one quarterback after a failed play “He starts crawling on all fours trying to get to me. He’s crawling in the dirt like it was the most important play in the world and I look at him and said ‘Jeez-us Deacon it ain’t the Super Bowl.’ But that’s how much he cared."

Over the next decade the "Secretary of Defense" established himself as one of the best players of all time—playing in eight Pro Bowls named to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1980 and even inventing the phrase "sacking the quarterback."  He believed that he could rise above.

He found a place at Mississippi Vocational College (an #HBCU) sleeping in cots in the other teams' gyms on away games because hotels wouldn't take him or the other Black students.  In 1961 he was drafted by the @Rams.

President Trump’s lengthy trial brief does not explain why even now he has not offered any documents or witnesses in his defense or provided any information in response to the House’s repeated requests. This is not how an innocent person behaves.

President Trump’s lengthy brief to the Senate is heavy on rhetoric and procedural grievances but entirely lacks a legitimate defense of his misconduct. It is clear from his response that President Trump would rather discuss anything other than what he actually did.

If the Senate does not convict and remove President Trump he will have succeeded in placing himself above the law. Each Senator should set aside partisanship and politics and hold President Trump accountable to protect our national security and democracy.

President Trump’s view that he cannot be held accountable except in an election he seeks to fix in his favor underscores the need for the Senate to exercise its solemn constitutional duty to remove President Trump from office.
Indeed on the eve of his impeachment trial President Trump continues to insist that he has done nothing wrong.

The ultimate check on Presidential misconduct was provided by the Framers through the power to impeach and remove a President—a power that the Framers vested in the representatives of the American people.
The Framers also knew that periodic democratic elections cannot serve as an effective check on a President who seeks to manipulate the those elections.

The Framers anticipated that a President might one day seek to place his own personal and political interests above those of our Nation and they understood that foreign interference in our elections was one of the gravest threats to our democracy.

There should be a fair trial — fair to the President yes but equally important fair to the American people. Any Senator who wants the same should reject the McConnell Resolution. https://t.co/KVDukoTEA7
A White House-driven and rigged process with a truncated schedule designed to go late into the night and further conceal the President’s misconduct is not what the American people expect or deserve.
The McConnell Resolution goes so far as to suggest it may not even allow the evidence gathered by the House to be admitted. That is not a fair trial. In fact it is no trial at all.
If those efforts are successful this will be the first impeachment trial in American history in which the Senate did not allow the House to present its case with witnesses and documents.
...Here McConnell is trying to prevent the witnesses from ever testifying and the public from ever finding out what they have to say.

And in the Clinton case all of the witnesses had testified before the Senate trial began and the only issue was whether they would be re-called to testify once more. The substance of what they would say was already known...
In the Clinton case the President provided all of the documents — more than 90000 pages of them — before the trial took place. McConnell’s resolution rejects that basic necessity.
His resolution deviates sharply from the Clinton precedent — and common sense — in an effort to prevent the full truth of the President’s misconduct from coming to light.

For weeks Mitch McConnell has asserted that he planned to follow the ‘Clinton precedent’ for structuring President Trump’s Senate impeachment trial. It is now clear why he hid his proposed resolution all this time and released it the night before the trial is set to begin.
President Trump maintains that the Senate cannot remove him even if the House proves every claim in the Articles of impeachment. That is a chilling assertion. It is also dead wrong.

The American Legion Dorie Miller Memorial Post 331 in West Orlando was named after Dorie Miller. My office joined them for a wreath laying ceremony on National Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day last December.  May he continue to inspire us for generations to come. https://t.co/zPXCNfwcgC

But during the surprise attack that morning he leaped to man an anti-aircraft gun and saved countless lives by carrying wounded sailors to safety as the ship was struck by torpedoes and bombs. His bravery earned him the Navy Cross never before given to a Black sailor.

On December 7 1941 a young Navy mess attendant named Doris 'Dorie' Miller was serving aboard the USS West Virginia docked in Pearl Harbor.  As a Black sailor his job was to swab decks cook and do other menial work.
